user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketAddrSetPort_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAddrSetPort_Impl(OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, uint16 PortNum)
{
    in_port_t               sa_port;
    OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    sa_port  = htons(PortNum);
    Accessor = (OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            Accessor->sa_in.sin_port = sa_port;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_port = sa_port;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketAddrSetPort_Impl:
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
typedef union
{
    char               data[OS_SOCKADDR_MAX_LEN];
    struct sockaddr    sa;
    struct sockaddr_in sa_in;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
    struct sockaddr_in6 sa_in6;
#endif
} OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t
...
#define OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6 
...
#define OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS (-34)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler-specific language extensions are used in the provided code. The code uses standard C features and POSIX/socket types: function-local declarations, casts, unions, preprocessor conditionals (#ifdef/#endif), and standard networking types/functions (in_port_t, htons, sockaddr family constants). There are no uses of known compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm, typeof, statement-expressions, nested functions, inline assembly, GNU statement labels, anonymous structures/unions beyond standard C union use, or other vendor-specific keywords. The conditional compilation symbol (OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6) is a standard preprocessor macro, not a language extension. Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
